Award.AwardTitle: Building an Integrated Identification, Engagement and Assessment Infrastructure for STEM Enrichment Programs at Hunter College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Building an Integrated Identification, Engagement and Assessment Infrastructure for STEM Enrichment Programs at Hunter College" is an award with a vision that includes transforming how STEM enrichment programs are made available to students at CUNY Hunter College, facilitating faculty work in the area of student education within STEM enrichment programs and collaboration across programs, and leveraging the intellectual capital of current grant-funded programs. The goals of the project are to:

1. Identify students for recruitment into the STEM programs at a much earlier time and broaden participation;
2. Expand the paths for information about and application to the programs at critical educational junctures;
3. Reinvent the mentoring of students in the programs and their research placements to better integrate research and education; and
4. Assess our effectiveness and track our students to create an information loop that will feed back into each stage of the process from recruitment to post-baccalaureate.

The five NSF awards upon which the I3 project will build include:
1. Math and Science Partnership in New York City (0412413 to CUNY City University of New York);
2. The Catalyst Scholarship Program (0850021 to CUNY Hunter College)
3. The Noyce Teacher Academy Scholar Program (0833134 to CUNY Hunter College);
4. MIND Alliance for Minority Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (0833392 to CUNY Hunter College); and
5. New York City Louis Stokes Alliance Phase IV (0703449 to CUNY City College).

The project team proposed to achieve the four stated goals by creating a multifaceted model of institutional integration for CUNY Hunter College. This model includes a new administrative function in the Office of the Provost complementing a Science Advisory Board; a plan to bring together faculty and professional staff from Student Services, Admissions, Institutional Research, Assessment, and Institutional Technology; a plan to implement new computer software technology for improved communication across the student, faculty and administrative communities; and a plan to create a sustainable infrastructure for the science programs which can accommodate growth and continued innovation. This work will focus on three primary areas: Student recruitment and identification, student engagement, and the creation of an information infrastructure for student tracking, reporting and assessment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding from this project was used in various ways as Hunter worked to build a culture of undergraduate research.  Hunter’s I-cubed project transformed the way STEM enrichment programs were made available to students at Hunter and facilitated the work of faculty in educating students in these programs and sharing information and opportunities across programs.  Results and finding from this project are currently in press (see manuscript attached). The project:

a)     identified students for recruitment into the STEM enrichment programs at a much earlier time;

b)     expanded the paths for information about and application to these programs at critical educational junctures;

c)     broadened participation in Hunter’s STEM enrichment programs;

d)     reinvented the mentoring of students in the programs and their research placements to better integrate research and education; and

e)     assessed program effectiveness and track student progress to inform and improve recruitment and retention into Hunter’s science programs and majors and enhance students’ opportunities once they graduate.

 

We have institutionalized several aspects of this project. These include the undergraduate research website, the research opportunities database, the comprehensive database to track student outcomes, professional development opportunities, and the annual Undergraduate Research Conference.  Some efforts, most notably the general application and the matching quiz, have been dropped, but after careful assessment of the efficacy of these programs, the original UGR team had concluded that few students were finding them useful, so it is likely that they too would have decided to discontinue supporting them, especially given how labor-intensive it is to keep them updated.
